topic.title: Stage 3 proposal: Feature #13035
topic.shortdesc: Provides an XML-mention domain for marking up mentions of XML syntactic components. This will benefit any document that talks about XML vocabularies, such as the DITA standard, documentation for XML applications, instructional materials for XML technologies, documentation of XML-based configuration files, and more.

section.title: Approved technical requirements
section.p: Define a markupDomain vocabulary module for generic mentions of markup names, and an xmlDomain vocabulary module defining XML-specific markup naming elements.

dlentry.dd: Markup domain. Mention of any markup-related name. This element serves as the specialization basis for all other elements.
XML domain. Mention of a numeric character reference
XML domain. Mention of a parameter entity
XML domain. A mention of a text entity
XML domain. Mention of an XML attribute
XML domain. Mention of an XML element type
XML domain. Mention of an XML namespace name
XML domain. Mention of an XML processing instruction name

section.title: Modified DTDs
section.p: This depends on whether we plan to integrate the XML mention domain into the base or technical content DTDs.

section.title: Modified specification documentation
section.p:
Adds 10 topics to the Language Reference:
Container topic for the markupDomain
Topic for the <markupname> element
Container topic for the xmlDomain
Topic for the <numcharref> element
Topic for the <parameterentity> element
Topic for the <textentity> element
Topic for the <xmlatt> element
Topic for the <xmlelement> element
Topic for the <xmlnsname> element
Topic for the <xmlpi> element This topic collection should be added to the current section 3.2.6 [Technical content] Domain elements. I suggest that it be placed in-between "User interface elements" and "xNAL domain elements".

reference.title: Markup domain
reference.shortdesc: The markup domain elements are used for the mention of named constructs in markup languages.

reference.title: markupname
reference.shortdesc: The <markupname> element identifies mentions of any named markup token, such as elements or attributes in XML or SGML. This element also serves as the specialization basis for the elements in the XML mention domain; when that domain is present, its more specific elements should be used instead of <markupname> when appropriate.

section.title: Example
section.codeblock: The <markupname>p.attributes</markupname> attribute group defines the allowed attributes for the <xmlelement>p</xmlelement> element.

reference.title: XML mention domain
reference.shortdesc: The XML-mention domain elements are used for mentions of named XML constructs, including elements, attributes, parameter entities, processing instructions, document type declaration components, and XSD and Relax NG schema components. These elements enable specific typographic effects for different construct types, precise search and retrieval of specific constructs, and automatic indexing of different constructs. This domain is intended to support the description and documentation of XML document types and XML applications.

reference.title: numcharref
reference.shortdesc:
The <numcharref> element identifies mentions of XML numeric character references (e.g., "
", "
"). This element enables more precise semantic searching of the DITA source; it also enables distinct output formatting. The content of the <numcharref> element should be just the numeric value, e.g. "10" or "x0a", with any leading or trailing characters added as a matter of style, e.g., the "&#" and ";" delimiters. This element is part of the XML mention domain.

section.title: Example
section.codeblock: Numeric character references represent characters from the Universal Character Set (UCS) of Unicode. They are used to reference characters that cannot easily be directly encoded in a document, such as a copyright symbol. When a markup-aware processor encounters a numeric character reference, for example, 225, it renders the reference as the Unicode character that it represents: a-acute.

reference.title: parameterentity
reference.shortdesc: The <parameterentity> element identifies mentions of parameter entities (e.g. "%keyword.content;"). This element enables more precise semantic searching of the DITA source; it also enables distinct formatting, such as adding the "%" and ";" delimiters to the parameter entity name. The content of the <parameterentity> element should be the entity name without the leading "%" or trailing ";". This element is part of the XML mention domain.

section.title: Examples
section.codeblock: ... The p.content parameter entity defines the content model for the p element.
To include the XML-mention domain in a DTD document-type shell, you must declare the xml-d-dec parameter entity.

reference.title: textentity
reference.shortdesc: The <textentity> element identifies mentions of XML text entities (e.g. "&xml-d-att;"). This element enables more precise semantic searching of the DITA source; it also enables distinct formatting, such as adding an ampersand (&) as a leading character and a semicolon (;) as a trailing character. The content of the <textentity> element should be the entity name without the "&" and ";" delimiters. This element is part of the XML mention domain.

section.title: Example
section.codeblock: The <textentity>hi-d-att</textentity> entity holds the contribution for the <xmlatt>domains</xmlatt> attribute.

reference.title: xmlatt
reference.shortdesc: The <xmlatt> element identifies mentions of XML attributes. This element enables more precise semantic searching of the DITA source; it also enables distinct formatting, such as preceding the name of the attribute with a commercial at (@) sign. The content of the <xmlatt> element should be the attribute name without any "@" or "=" characters. This element is part of the XML mention domain.

section.title: Example
section.codeblock: The <xmlatt>collection-type</xmlatt> and <xmlatt>linking</xmlatt> attributes affect how related links are generated for topics that are referenced in the DITA map.

reference.title: xmlelement
reference.shortdesc: The <xmlelement> element identifies mentions of XML element types. This element enables more precise semantic searching of the DITA source; it also enables distinct formatting, such as surrounding the name of the element with angle brackets. The content of the <xmlelement> element should be the element type name without leading or training angle brackets. This element is part of the XML mention domain.

section.title: Example
section.codeblock: Use the uicontrol (user interface control) element to indicate the names of buttons, entry fields, menu items, or other objects that enable a user to interact with a graphical user interface.

reference.title: xmlnsname
reference.shortdesc: The <xmlnsname> element identifies mentionds of namespace names (e.g., "http://dita.oasis-open.org/architecture/2005/"). This element enables more precise semantic searching of the DITA source; it also enables distinct formatting. This element is part of the XML mention domain.

section.title: Example
section.codeblock: The namespace name for XHTML is <xmlnamespace>http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml</xmlnamespace>.

reference.title: xmlpi
reference.shortdesc: The <xmlpi> element identifies mentions of processing instruction names (e.g., "<?piname pi value"). This element enables more precise semantic searching of the DITA source; it also enables distinct formatting. This element is part of the XML mention domain.

section.title: Example
section.codeblock: While DITA does not define any processing instructions, you may be able to use the DocBook processing instructions, such as <xmlpi>dbhtml_bgcolor</xmlpi>.
